comment.body: I still get `SystemError: Cannot modify a string currently used` when trying to use this to build other things (e.g. lxml).

issue.title: Adapt to C-API changes in CPython 3.13
[BUG] Operations with variable annotated with `int` avoids optimisations
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

When variable has type `int` in pure python mode, Cython is using generic `PyObject_RichCompare` instead of optimised `__Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC` which is used when no annotation is used.

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

```python
def bar(a: int):
    print(a == 5)

bar()
```

Generated C code:

```c
  /* "deleteme.py":23
 * 
 * def bar(a: int):
 *     print(a == 5)             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 * 
 * bar()
 */
  __pyx_t_1 = PyObject_RichCompare(__pyx_v_a, __pyx_int_5, Py_EQ); __Pyx_XGOTREF(__pyx_t_1); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 23, __pyx_L1_error)
```

### Expected behaviour

```python
def bar(a):
    print(a == 5)

bar()
```

Generated C code:
```c
  /* "deleteme.py":23
 * 
 * def bar(a):
 *     print(a == 5)             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 * 
 * bar()
 */
  __pyx_t_1 = __Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC(__pyx_v_a, __pyx_int_5, 5, 0); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 23, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
```

### OS

MacOS

### Python version

3.9

### Cython version

master

### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
> 1. New method needs to be added for `int` type - `_handle_simple_method_int___eq__`:

I'm sure you've spotted it, but this issue (and fix) applies to most other binops too (i.e. add, sub, etc)

issue.title: [BUG] Operations with variable annotated with `int` avoids optimisations
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

When variable has type `int` in pure python mode, Cython is using generic `PyObject_RichCompare` instead of optimised `__Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC` which is used when no annotation is used.

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

```python
def bar(a: int):
    print(a == 5)

bar()
```

Generated C code:

```c
  /* "deleteme.py":23
 * 
 * def bar(a: int):
 *     print(a == 5)             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 * 
 * bar()
 */
  __pyx_t_1 = PyObject_RichCompare(__pyx_v_a, __pyx_int_5, Py_EQ); __Pyx_XGOTREF(__pyx_t_1); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 23, __pyx_L1_error)
```

### Expected behaviour

```python
def bar(a):
    print(a == 5)

bar()
```

Generated C code:
```c
  /* "deleteme.py":23
 * 
 * def bar(a):
 *     print(a == 5)             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 * 
 * bar()
 */
  __pyx_t_1 = __Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC(__pyx_v_a, __pyx_int_5, 5, 0); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 23, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
```

### OS

MacOS

### Python version

3.9

### Cython version

master

### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
> I suspect what's happened is that the check is probably based on is py_object_type and we assume anything typed with something else isn't an int.

Yes there are two places:
1. New method needs to be added for `int` type - `_handle_simple_method_int___eq__`:
 https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/edaea23cc5a7909e84d3bd01b0a8ab2206af8e95/Cython/Compiler/Optimize.py#L3425
2. `int` type needs to be added to this line:
 https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/edaea23cc5a7909e84d3bd01b0a8ab2206af8e95/Cython/Compiler/Optimize.py#L4210
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/edaea23cc5a7909e84d3bd01b0a8ab2206af8e95/Cython/Compiler/Optimize.py#L4215

issue.title: Add (and use) vectorcall utility-code functions
issue.body:
### Describe your issue

For the Limited API (and elsewhere) we're sometimes needing to fall back to standard Python calls (a recent example is `int.from_bytes`).

`PyObject_Vectorcall` and `PyObject_VectorcallMethod` and available in Limited API 3.12 upwards, and the regular API for much longer. It'd be good to be able to use those where available, without too much code duplication. Cython currently only provides utility code that wraps `PyObject_VectorcallDict`, which is a worse choice where keyword arguments are involved since it involves creating an extra dict, and extracting the out.

Therefore we should ideally also have utility code that wraps something close to the real vectorcall interface. It might be worth passing the keyword arguments as a C array rather than a tuple to avoid unnecessary tuple creation when the real vectorcall interface isn't available though (or having both options available).

It'd also be worth using these in our regular code-generation for `GeneralCallNode` when known keyword arguments are involved. e.g.

```
from xxx import f

def call_f(a, b, c):
    f(a, b, c=c, d="d")
```

still uses the call protocol rather than the vectorcall protocol.

So don't this helps both utility code and regular code generation.

issue.title: [BUG] Operations with variable annotated with `int` avoids optimisations
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

When variable has type `int` in pure python mode, Cython is using generic `PyObject_RichCompare` instead of optimised `__Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC` which is used when no annotation is used.

### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

```python
def bar(a: int):
    print(a == 5)

bar()
```

Generated C code:

```c
  /* "deleteme.py":23
 * 
 * def bar(a: int):
 *     print(a == 5)             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 * 
 * bar()
 */
  __pyx_t_1 = PyObject_RichCompare(__pyx_v_a, __pyx_int_5, Py_EQ); __Pyx_XGOTREF(__pyx_t_1); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 23, __pyx_L1_error)
```

### Expected behaviour

```python
def bar(a):
    print(a == 5)

bar()
```

Generated C code:
```c
  /* "deleteme.py":23
 * 
 * def bar(a):
 *     print(a == 5)             # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 * 
 * bar()
 */
  __pyx_t_1 = __Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC(__pyx_v_a, __pyx_int_5, 5, 0); if (unlikely(!__pyx_t_1)) __PYX_ERR(0, 23, __pyx_L1_error)
  __Pyx_GOTREF(__pyx_t_1);
```

### OS

MacOS

### Python version

3.9

### Cython version

master

### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
I suspect what's happened is that the check is probably based on `is py_object_type` and we assume anything typed with something else *isn't* an int.

We could probably do better though if we really wanted:
`__Pyx_PyInt_EqObjC` is written with the assumption that `a` is probably an `int` but doesn't have to be. So we could generate a more specific function for this.


### OS

MacOS

master

_No response_

forkee.name: cython
forkee.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler

comment.body: So in principle if the limited API is version is greater than 3.12 we could also use `PyObject_VectorcallMethod` and it'll be a bit faster. I had a quick go and it was (and I can submit a PR for that if you want). But I suspect really we'd want to abstract that into a wrapper so we don't have to rewrite it for every repetition of it.

issue.title: Stop fallback indexing code using PySequence_*Item first
issue.body:
since this behaves differently to the PyObject functions.

Fixes #5776 and some indexing bugs on PyPy and the Limited API

comment.body:
> We have to call either PyMapping_GetItem() or PySequence_GetItem(), so if it's not the one, we call the other.

Okay, I see. The alternative fallback is to call `PyObject_GetItem` which would only try `tp_as_mapping` before again calling `PySequence_GetItem`. So if `PyMapping_Check` is false then we can cut straight to `PySequence_GetItem` to skip out converting the C integer to a Python integer and back.

issue.title: Stop fallback indexing code using PySequence_*Item first
issue.body:
since this behaves differently to the PyObject functions.

Fixes #5776 and some indexing bugs on PyPy and the Limited API

comment.body:
>When would it ever be safe to use `PySequence_GetItem` if you don't know explicitly that the object is a concrete sequence type like list or tuple?

We have to call either PyMapping_GetItem() or PySequence_GetItem(), so if it's not the one, we call the other. If that fails, we get the expected exception.
When would it ever be safe to use `PySequence_GetItem` if you don't know explicitly that the object is a concrete sequence type like list or tuple?
